Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Situation2: They remain cheerful and patient while handling an upset customer during a peak holiday rush.
Story: I glanced at my phone during my break, a message from Alex lighting up the screen: “Which night are we having our date? I miss you.” I smiled, warmth blooming in my chest. We’d both managed to carve out a few free evenings this week, a rare treat. I wanted to pick the perfect night, to give him my full attention, to make up for all the times work had gotten in the way. But as I tucked my phone away and returned to the register, the holiday rush hit me like a wave. The line snaked past the candy displays, and a woman at the front was already raising her voice, frustrated about a coupon. I forced a smile, trying to stay patient and friendly, even as my heart pounded. My manager’s words echoed in my mind: “No matter how busy, always be cheerful.” I felt pulled in two directions—wanting to be the attentive girlfriend Alex deserved, but also the reliable cashier my job demanded. My mind raced, torn between texting Alex back right away or focusing on the upset customer in front of me.
